entry.title: Selection of optimal scenario for Selective Data Transition to SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
This article is part of a series exploring SAP's Selective Data Transition Engagement (SDTE). In a previous blog, we provided an overview and the main value drivers of the SDT transition approach from SAP ECC to SAP S/4HANA. In this article, we will discuss the optimal selection of an SDT scenario. Upcoming instalments will delve into methodology, tools, and more to clarify SDTE and showcase its benefits.

 

Transformation requirements

Enterprises operating on SAP ERP and considering a transition to SAP S/4HANA may have varying starting points and needs. Some may see the transition as a move to the next generation of software with minimal changes in system functionality and data. Others may use the SAP S/4HANA transition to revamp their system's foundation to better support current and future business needs, eliminating obsolete data and developments while introducing new features and innovations. Transformation requirements often depend on:

  • How long ago and how optimally the SAP ERP systems were implemented, and how significantly business models, structures, and processes have changed since then.
  • How prepared the current systems are to support business strategy, growth, and innovations.
  • The roadmap chosen by the enterprise for transformation, including investments planned before, during, and after the transition to SAP S/4HANA.

Selective Data Transition provides the flexibility to incorporate desired changes within the scope of the SAP S/4HANA transition project, encompassing multiple transition scenarios rather than one. Different scenarios may be optimal for different enterprises based on transformation and data migration requirements.

In the following sections, we will explore these scenarios and discuss how to select the most suitable one for your specific requirements. We'll begin with an overview of options for creating the target system and then examine various data migration scenarios.

 

Target system creation

Every SDT project begins with the decision on how the target SAP S/4HANA system will be created. The target system, also known as the "golden shell" or "golden template," is a system created at the start of the SDT project. It serves as the foundation for all systems within the SAP S/4HANA project and maintenance landscapes, including the future productive system.

Option 1. Shell conversion

The first option, "shell conversion," is suitable if most of your current SAP ERP assets (configured solutions, developments, data) need to be preserved and transitioned to SAP S/4HANA.

  1. Using a client copy or specific tools, create an empty copy of SAP ECC with all customizing and repository (code) but without any application data. This system is called the "SAP ECC shell."
  2. Perform required housekeeping activities in the empty SAP ECC shell system, such as removing unnecessary company codes. Unicode conversion or upgrades may be completed to meet system conversion prerequisites if required.
  3. Execute all activities necessary to prepare this system for conversion to SAP S/4HANA (data preparation is not required since there is no data in the system).
  4. Convert the prepared SAP ECC shell to SAP S/4HANA using a standard conversion toolset and complete SPAU, SPDD and post-conversion activities. This system becomes the "golden shell" of SAP S/4HANA—a template for all future SAP S/4HANA systems, created as copies of the golden shell.
  5. Implement custom code adjustments and customizing changes required for simplification items or additional business requirements in the development system (a copy of the golden shell).
  6. Necessary data can be migrated to the copy of the configured system. More details on data migration scenarios described below.

Option 2. Mix and Match

The second option is suitable when most processes require modifications, and it becomes necessary to substantially reimplement the system. This approach supports these changes while retaining certain investments, such as configured solutions, developments, and data, for the transition to SAP S/4HANA.

In this scenario, a new SAP S/4HANA system is deployed, with standard content activated as necessary. Unlike a greenfield implementation, the target system will be enhanced by transferring selected elements from SAP ECC or an intermediate ECC system. This enhancement is supported by specialized tools.

The most common scenarios are illustrated in the image above.

Option 3. Special case – Systems Consolidation

When it is necessary to consolidate multiple SAP ECC systems into a single instance of SAP S/4HANA, and there are significant similarities among the ECC systems, variations of options 1 and 2 can be utilized to create the target system, depending on specific requirements. A typical scenario is as follows:

  1. Select one of the consolidated systems as the main target.
  2. Create an SAP ECC shell from this system.
  3. Compare customization and repository of this SAP ECC shell with all the SAP ECC systems that will be consolidated manually or using specific tools, highlighting any identified differences.
  4. Analyze the differences and document how to resolve conflicts, collecting mappings between settings in the source and target systems to be used in the later data migration.
  5. Consolidate customizing and repositories in the SAP ECC shell system manually or using special tools based on documented decisions.
  6. Prepare the consolidated SAP ECC shell for conversion to SAP S/4HANA and convert it into the golden shell of SAP S/4HANA.

Once the target system is ready, an SAP S/4HANA development system is usually created as a copy to perform necessary application-specific customizing and custom-code adjustments. Completion of these prepares the system for data migration and testing.

 

SDT Scenarios Overview

SDT scenarios described below represent best practices commonly used in SDTE community projects. Even if the terms or names may slightly vary among different partners, the meaning and practices remain consistent within the community. After creating the target SAP S/4HANA system, finding an optimal path for data migration addressing specific requirements is essential.

Scenario 1. Regular SDT – table-based data migration and transformation

In this scenario, selected SAP ERP system data is migrated to SAP S/4HANA at the database table level using specialized tools. Specific considerations include:

  • Target system creation is preferably achieved via the shell conversion.
  • Table-based migration enables fast data transfer, resulting in short downtime since migration occurs at the database level. Unlike posting based technology (e.g. Migration Cockpit) no application-level logic is executed for the data migration, thus careful data validation and process testing is crucial post-migration.
  • Required transformation routines are executed in the SAP S/4HANA target system post or during migration to transform the data into the SAP S/4HANA data model.
  • Historical transactional data can be migrated using this approach, with filters applicable based on organizational units (e.g., data for selected company codes) or time slices (e.g., the last three years of data), or individual filters for data migration objects. Data cleansing and preparation of the migrated data in source systems may be needed (for example consistency of finance historical data).
  • Go-live can be scheduled at any time during the fiscal year, as all necessary data for finance reporting is usually migrated, avoiding data slicing between systems.
  • Downtime for source and target systems is usually required during the table-based migration.
  • Transformations can be applied to migrated data based on mappings, renaming, or renumbering logic. Some S/4HANA transformation pre-projects (e.g., Business Partners creation) may be embedded in the SDT migration process. However, limitations may exist on integrating many "on-the-fly" transformations simultaneously on the same data set at the same time.

Scenario 2. Lean SDT – selective table-based data migration without transformation requirements

Lean Selective Data Transition is the standard solution provided by SAP for identifying and transferring relevant data during migration from SAP ECC to SAP S/4HANA using the SAP Business Transformation Center. Technically, Lean SDT resembles Option 1: shell creation is necessary, and all data migrates at the table level with organizational unit or time slice filters. However, Lean SDT offers no data transformations and no systems consolidation, whereas regular SDT provides more flexibility and broader transformation possibilities.

Scenario 3. Hybrid SDT – combination of table-based data migration & postings

In this scenario, selected SAP ERP data for specific areas (e.g., master data, logistics, plant maintenance) migrated to SAP S/4HANA at the database table level using special tools, while postings (using tools like SAP Migration Cockpit or specific consulting tools) are used for other data objects (e.g., finance open items, balances, and inventory stocks). Specific considerations include:

  • Postings trigger application-level validations of migrated data, increasing confidence in data quality within the target system. However, postings may take longer than table-based migration and require higher data cleansing standards.
  • Historical transactional data cannot be migrated using standard posting methodologies. Only current open orders, open items, balances, and stocks can be transferred to the target instance.
  • Go-live is advisable at the beginning of the fiscal year, as data needed for finance reporting may be sliced between systems otherwise, impacting migration scope and efforts (P&L, assets).
  • Postings occur through data re-creation using API (BAPI) in the target system considering local system settings. Therefore, postings provide a simplified option to redesign functional and structural changes, at the expense of loss of historical data.

 

SDT Scenario Selection

Selecting an optimal SDT scenario is primarily driven by transformation and data migration requirements and includes decisions on the target system creation option and data migration approach.

Decision on a target system creation option depends on the changes needed in the system functionality and structures. This influences the scope of the transformation. The shell creation approach predominantly reuses current SAP ERP system customizing and repository, indicating that migrated data mostly fits the new system as it is in the source. The Mix and Match approach suggests that primarily spot solutions will remain unchanged in the future SAP S/4HANA compared to the current SAP ERP, starting from a new fresh system reducing the data migration scope/volume and increasing complexity of transformation.

To select an optimal data migration strategy, it is essential to identify, at least at a high level, the mandatory and desired functional and structural changes (transformations) that will occur in the new SAP S/4HANA system compared to the existing SAP ERP. This question is closely related to data migration scope. Migrating historical transactional data means all required transformations must occur within this data, which can be complex and challenging for certain transformations and data objects.

Project risks, efforts, and duration can be managed with a balanced approach between functional transformations and data migration scope. If functional transformations are driven by changes in business models and processes, they cannot usually be sacrificed and must be executed during the SAP S/4HANA transition. In such cases, data migration scope can be limited to postings of master data and open items to new structures in heavily transformed areas.

Other factors influencing scenario selection include planned go-live date (beginning of fiscal year or not), systems consolidation needs, data volumes, downtime requirements, and potential for transformational pre- or post-projects.

To summarize, selecting the optimal SDT scenario requires knowledge of:

  • Mandatory and desired functional and structural changes (transformations) in the new SAP S/4HANA system compared to the existing SAP ERP.
  • Required data migration scope in different areas (Finance, Logistics/Operation, HR).
  • Downtime, go-live date, system consolidation, and other special requirements.

These topics must be discussed all together since they influence each other. A balanced approach might be required to select the most optimal SDT scenario that will provide the safest, easiest, and fastest pathway to SAP S/4HANA target architecture.

 

Success Stories

German manufacturer in the food sector: Selective Data Transition of the last 2 years

The customer moved document date from the last two years from his old ECC into S/4HANA environment.

SDTE Properties in Action:

  • Shell creation: Technical preparation of the future S/4HANA target system
  • Filtered selection: Time slice level to just bring the necessary organizational structures with current and last two fiscal year into the new environment
  • SDT transformation approach: CO area restructuring (mainly merging, but also some splits), chart of accounts harmonization, introduction of New GL and New Asset Accounting, introduction of group currency

Energy Industry (Germany): Selective Data Transition with filtered migration

The customer moved from his 20-year-old SAP ECC into a new SAP S/4HANA environment including a separation of energy industry specific data (SAP IS-U) from core ERP logistic and finance data.

SDTE Properties in Action:

  • Shell creation: Technical preparation of the future S/4HANA target system
  • Filtered selection: Filter on organizational and time slice level to just bring the necessary organizational structures with current and last fiscal year into the new environment
  • SDT transformation approach: Regular SDT including transformations like a controlling area split and bringing the data into the S/4HANA data model

 

Call to Action

You’ve seen that selecting an optimal SDT scenario is primarily driven by transformation and data migration scope requirements and includes decisions on the target system creation option and data migration approach.

In the next episode, we will discuss the advantages of systems consolidation and SDT usage for that purpose.

In the meantime:

  1. Explore Webinars & Resources
    Discover more about SDTE via official SAP Support Portal webinars or community sessions that dive deeper into the specifics.
  2. Contact the SDTE Community
    Reach out to the expert group of SAP and its partners for an assessment of your current landscape. They can help identify how selective data transition can best fit your needs.
  3. Start Your Transformation
    Don’t wait until maintenance windows close or all experts are not available anymore. A well-planned selective data migration can future-proof your IT environment and jump-start your intelligent enterprise journey.

Take the next step by visiting
SDTE Engagement Overview
to connect with the SDTE community and chart out your custom path to SAP S/4HANA success.

entry.title: Enterprise Management Layer for SAP S/4HANA - New Release (OP2023 - SPS04) Announcement
entry.content:
Our enterprise management layer template based on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition OP2023 has been upgraded with some content released for SPS04 and will soon be available for customers to buy from SAP. We are aiming for mid-September 2025.

The new release does not include major scope item updates (addition, updates, obsolete), but provides an upgraded template with some OSS notes delivered by SPS04 being applied, essentially in the context of Localization. 

In the context of Localization, the following documents/scope items have been updated (new version):

  • EML_2023_DRC01_BPD_EN_XX_V1.3.1
  • EML_2023_LOC01_BPD_EN_XX_V1.3.1
  • EML_2023_LOC11_BPD_EN_EE_V1.3.1
  • EML_2023_LOC11_BPD_EN_IN_V1.3.1
  • EML_2023_LOC11_BPD_EN_PL_V1.3.1

Below is an overview of the latest updates in the context of Localization:

CountryFeatureScope Item
AEBusiness Partners CertificatesLOC01
ATEC Sales List1J2
BEVAT ReturnLOC01
BEEC Sales ListLOC01
CARecapture of Input Tax Credits (RITC) Report1J2
CATax Codes Rates AdjustmentsLOC01
CHBalance of PaymentsLOC01
CZVAT Return VersionLOC01
DEEC Sales ListLOC01
DKElectronic invoicing via PEPPOL network under format OIOUBL 2.1DRC01
EERevised Tax Codes RatesLOC11_EE
FRVAT Return1J2
LOC01
FROverdue Invoices1J2
LOC01
GBPayment Practices and Performance1J2
LOC01
HUVAT Return1J2
J58
HUMonthly VAT Declaration Format (2025)LOC01
HUVAT Declaration (Reverse Charge Mechanism)LOC01
INTax Collected at Source (TCS)J60
LOC11_IN
INGSTR-6 Report and Input Service Distributors (ISD)LOC11_IN
INDepreciation of Assets as per Income Tax LawLOC11_IN
KRManufacturing Cost StatementLOC01
MYElectronic Customer Invoices and Buyer-Issued: Tax Authorities Clearance – sending by emailDRC01
MYEnhancements in Creating Consolidated Electronic InvoicesDRC01
MYMixed Tax Type electronic invoicesDRC01
MYEnabling of Buyer-Issued Electronic Refund NotesDRC01
MYElectronic Customer Invoices: ExchangeDRC01
NLFinancial Audit File1J2
NZBank Number and Bank Accounts ValidationLOC01
PHVAT Return (Monthly and Quarterly)1J2
PLSAF-TJ60
LOC11_PL
PLSAF-T JPK-VAT Monthly/QuarterlyLOC11_PL
PLSAF-T JPK_KR_PD YearlyLOC11_PL
PLSAF-T JPK_ST_KR YearlyLOC11_PL
PTAnnual Sales and Purchase (Annex O and P) and Annual VAT Declaration (Annex L and M)1J2
LOC01
RONew VAT Rates from August 1st, 2025LOC01
TWElectronic Invoices with Mixed Tax CodesDRC01
XXCustomer eInvoicing – submission via email based on Business Partner FunctionsDRC01
XXCustomer eInvoicing – One-Time Customers submission via emailDRC01
XXSupplier eInvoicing – submission via emailDRC01
XXSending Electronic Documents Through the Peppol Network Using Global Location Number (GLN)DRC01

Some further enhancements/updates are also provided:

  • Under Service Option VP01 - Intercompany Sales and Returns, it is now possible to create delivery related pro-forma Intercompany Invoices, see scope items “Advanced Intercompany Sales (5D2)” and “Accelerated Returns to Central Stock with VSIT Replacement Delivery (IC31V)”.
  • Under Service Option VP02 - Cross-Plant Stock Transfer, we have added scope item SC23 Cross-Plant Stock Transfer with STO with EWM in both Plants and Exceptions. This scope item addresses how to deal with quantity shortages during put away, its clearance and follow up activities.
  • Under Service Option VP07 - Intercompany Billing of Services, we have added scope item SRV30 Intercompany Billing of Service Orders – In House Repair. The scope items describes how an affiliate company supplies repair services on items returned from a customer to an ordering company. The supplying company records time on an intercompany service order as basis for Intercompany billing.  After repair, the ordering company send the repaired item back to the customer and creates a customer billing document for the repair services.

You can refer to our previous enterprise management layer template version based on FPS03, which contained the wider scope updates, here: Enterprise Management Layer for SAP S/4HANA - New ... - SAP Community.

entry.title: SLALITTYPEs for Ordinary Depreciation Related to Current / Prior Year Acquisition
entry.content:
Purpose

SLALITTYPE stands for Subledger-Specific Line Item Type. Together with MOVCAT (Transaction Type Category), it tells you the business meaning of current line item. Experienced users are very familiar with SLALITTYPEs. However, some other users still ask about it from time to time. So, it is worth an article to give some more explanation.

This article starts with the concepts of SLALITTYPE and MOVCAT, and then gives you a couple of examples to explain you how they work together.

⚠️To make the explanation easier, this article mainly focuses on the SLALITTYPEs for ordinary depreciation, because it is most commonly used. Special depreciation works in a similar way,

SLALITTYPEs for Acquisition

Every fixed asset starts its useful life with an acquisition. This article starts from here too. The most commonly used SLALITYPEs for acquisitions are:

  • 7000 - Cumulative Acquisition Costs
  • 7040 - Acquisition Costs for Current Year

⚠️All SLALITTYPEs from Asset Accounting start with 07.  

SLALITTYPEs for Ordinary Depreciation

SLALITTYPEs for ordinary depreciation has a coding convesion in the suffix, as you might have already noticed. For example:

SLALITTYPE SuffixStand For
5Ordinary Depreciation
6Special Depreciation
7Unplanned Depreciation

The following SLALITTYPEs related to ordinary depreciation are most frequently used.

  • 07005: Cumulative Ordinary Depreciation
  • 07025: Ordinary Depreciation Related to Prior Year Acquisition
  • 07045: Ordinary Depreciation Related to Current Year Acquisition
  • 07205: Ordinary Depreciation, Posted Periodically

SLALITTYPEs and Transaction Type Category (MOVCATs)

A SLALITTYPE can tell you the type of depreciation in the current line-item. But it does not tell you which transaction this depreciation amount relates to. For this purpose, you need Transaction Type Category (MOVCAT) in addition.

Here is a list of most frequently used MOVCATs.

  • 00 Balance Carry-Forward (BCF)
  • 06 Depreciation Run
  • 11 Acquisition
  • 12 Retirement
  • 13 Transfer Acquisition
  • 14 Transfer Retirement
  • 15 Post-Capitalization
  • 46 Manual Depreciation
  • 65 Revaluation

You will find more details in the rest of this article about how the SLALITTYPEs work together with MOVCATs.

SLALITTYPE 07205

07205 is only used in depreciation posting. That is to say, the T-Code AFAB posts ordinary depreciations with this SLALITTYPE 07205. And that is why in most cases the corresponding MOVCAT is 06 (Depreciation Run).

SLALITTYPE 07025 and 07045

Both SLALITTYPEs are used for value adjustments in ordinary depreciations, which are related to corresponding transactional postings. Again, you should look at the MOVCAT to know which business transaction it is in the current line item.

For example, you may find the following combinations of MOVCATs and SLALITTYPEs in your line items. 

MOVCATSLALITTYPEMeaning
11 (Acquisition)07025 Value Adjustment in Ordinary Depreciation, related to the (gross) acquisition in the prior year
12 (Retirement)07045Value Adjustment in Ordinary Depreciation, related to the retirement in the current year

Someone may take 07025 as an ordinary depreciation posted in the prior year, and 07045 as the one posted in the current year. This understanding is completely wrong!

As their descriptions suggest, 07025 and 07045 are different in the relations to their acquisitions. If a depreciation is calculated based on the acquistion of current year, system uses 07045. Otherwise, 07025 is taken.

SLALITTYPE 07005

It stands for accumulated ordinary depreciation. When it is combined with different MOVCATs, the current line item has different meanings. For example:

MOVCATMeaning
00 (Balance Carry-Forward)Accumulated Ordinary Depreciation at fiscal year start, carried-forward from the prior year.
11 (Acquisition)Value Adjustment in Ordinary Depreciation, related to the (gross) acquisition in the prior year
12 (Retirement)Value Adjustment in Ordinary Depreciation, related to the retirement in the prior year

Example - Gross Acquisition

Let's say a company code has two open fiscal years: 2024 & 2025. And the fiscal year variant is K4, meaning fiscal year aligned with calendar year.

The requirement is to post the following gross acquisition:

  • Date for gross acquisition 2025-07-01.
  • Prior year APC: 12,000 EUR
  • Prior year posted depreciation: -1,200 EUR
  • Current year depreciation (up to end of Jun 2025): -600 EUR

Enter the following line items in the T-code AB01 with transaction type 158, and with the posting date 2025-07-01.

SLALITTYPEMOVCATAmountRemarks
07000 - Cumulative APC1112,000 EURThe APC is from the prior year 2024.
07005 - Cumulative Ordinary Depr.11-1,200 EURThe depreciation is from the prior year 2024 (up to 2024-12-31)
07025 - Ordinary Depr. Related to Prior Year Acquisition11-600 EUR

This depreciation is for the 1st half of 2025.
But it is related to the acquisition from 2024.

⚠️There is no line item for 07045 at all. Because this acqusition is not for current year 2025. 

Example - Full Retirement (Scrapping)

Again, our company code has two open fiscal years: 2024 & 2025. And the fiscal year variant is K4, meaning fiscal year aligned with calendar year.

We have an asset with the depreciation key LINS:

  • It is a straight-line depreciation.
  • The depreciation is based on netbook value (NBV) over the remaining useful life.

This asset has 10 years' useful life and two acquisitions:

ACQ #1 - 2024 (prior year)With APC amount 1,200 EUR

ACQ #2 - 2025 (current year)

With APC amount 2,400 EUR

The ordinary depreciations in 2024 and 2025 are calculated as following. 

YearBase Value (Year-Start) Annual Ordinary DepreciationNBV (Year-End)
20241,200 EUR-120 EUR1,080 EUR
20253,480 EUR
=2,400 + 1,080		-387 EUR
= 3,480 / 9  (9 years left)		3,093 EUR

Now scrap the whole asset on Apr. 1 of 2025 (T-Code ABAVL). And you will see how different SLALITTYPEs are used in the following line items.

 SLALITTYPEMOVCATAmountRemarks
Retire 2024 - ACQ #10700012-1,200 EUR 
Retire 2024 - ACQ #10700512    120 EUR 
Retire 2025 - ACQ #10702512      30 EUR1/4 of 120 (Depreciation related to ACQ #1 from prior year 2024)
Retire 2025 - ACQ #20704012-2,400 EUR 
Retire 2025 - ACQ #20704512      67 EUR1/4 of 267 (= 387-120, Depr. related to ACQ #2 from current year 2025)

SLALITTYPE and Posting Schema

Posting schema is another complex topic. It is too much to describe it here too. But is worth mentioning how a SLALITTYPE is derived from a posting schema.

Run the t-code ABUZSM and you will find lots of pre-defined posting schema. For example, SAP_100_001 is for acquisition. There you will find the first line item as following.

With this schema, posting kernle will do the following:

  • Symbolic account KTANSW will be mapped to a G/L account via account determination.
  • Symbolic amount 01 will be mapped to a SLALITTYPE
    • If it is an acquisition for current year, the SLALITTYPE is 7040.
    • If it is an acquisition for prior year, the SLALITTYPE is 7000.

Summary

SLALITTYPE and MOVCAT are very important in Asset Accounting. It will be especially helpful when you want to build your asset reporting with your own-tailored key figures.

entry.title: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Adding a GUI transaction to the launchpad in SAP S/4HANA 2023 or higher
entry.content:
Latest update:

  • September 2025 - As per discussions with a recent customer... we recommend using app Launchpad Content Manager Client-Specific to create/change business catalogs + add/remove catalogs to business roles.  Adding the catalog to the business role in the LCM is more efficient (fewer clicks) than using PFCG, and updates the role menu. It does NOT automatically adjust authorizations. Security administrators still need to perform final adjustments using program PRGN_COMPARE_ROLE_MENU.  An mass maintenance alternative  to Launchpad Content Manager Client-Specific where there are many role to catalog assignments is program PRGN_CREATE_FIORIFRONTENDROLE.

TL;DR: Yes, you can add your custom GUI transactions (aka "Z transactions") to the SAP Fiori launchpad.

  1. Quickly understand the concept of adding launchpad content in learning video: Bringing Apps Onto SAP Fiori Launchpad for SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition [05:25]
  2. Your most important step is to create the Launchpad App Descriptor Item using the tool Launchpad App Manager.
  3. Your most important decision for each LADI is deciding which Semantic Object to assign to the transaction, as the Semantic Object drives intent-based navigation across the launchpad, i.e. where the tile or link to the transaction will appear in app-to-app navigation.

Screenshots in this blog post are from a Cloud Appliance Trial system SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS03.

 

Why you might need to add a GUI transaction to the SAP Fiori launchpad

Often system conversion customers have created several custom (aka “Z”) transactions in SAP ECC that they intend to continue using in SAP S/4HANA. They need to bring these custom transactions into the SAP Fiori launchpad to create a unified user experience across new SAP Fiori apps and classic UIs (including SAP GUI transactions).

While SAP provides launchpad content entries for most of the SAP delivered transactions, you may occasionally find a transaction that has been missed or excluded, and you can add your own entry. For example, an administration transaction for an industry solution.

Recommendation: If you have many custom transactions to bring onto the Fiori launchpad, consider adding them over time starting with the highest usage to least usage. You can use transaction ST03N to determine the usage of your custom transactions.  

In this blog post you will find:

  • Steps to add a GUI transaction to the Fiori launchpad
  • Understanding Launchpad App Descriptor Items for GUI transactions
  • How to create a Launchpad App Descriptor Item for a GUI transaction
  • Improve Navigation with Parameters

 

Steps to add a GUI transaction to the Fiori launchpad

1. Your most important step is to create the Launchpad App Descriptor Item (LADI) using the tool Launchpad App Manager.  A LADI literally describes an app that can be launched from the Fiori launchpad. This includes which app needs to be launched, what parameters may be passed when the app is launched, and the tile or link that the user selects to launch the app.  The LADI covers launching the app either directly from a page or indirectly from another app.

  • Your most important decision when creating the LADI is deciding which Semantic Object to assign to the transaction, as the Semantic Object drives intent-based navigation across the launchpad, i.e. where the tile or link to the transaction will appear. You maximize use of SAP predefined Semantic Objects to make the most of the navigation benefits.
  • Make sure you provide a user-meaningful tile title and link title.   This will help your users recognize and find the transaction.
  • It’s a good idea to include the transaction code (aka tcode) as a tile keyword for Search on Apps.  This helps users who are transitioning from SAP GUI to SAP Fiori and already know their tcodes. 
  • You can optionally add parameters to be passed to the transaction when it is launched.

2. Once the LADI has been created you can assign it to users in the same manner as predefined content provided by SAP.   For example, you:

  • Reference your custom transaction LADI to one or more business catalogs using the tool Launchpad Content Manager.
  • Update the business catalog assignment to the user’s business roles using the Role Maintenance transaction PFCG or program PRGN_COMPARE_ROLE_MENU.  If needed, you can also adjust data authorizations for the role.
  • Optionally add a tile for your LADI on pages using the SAP Fiori app F4512 Manage Launchpad Pages. 

IMPORTANT: You can come back and change the entry any time in the Launchpad App Manager. Changes are automatically and immediately (caching permitting) reflected wherever the LADI is used. 

Hint: You can find which spaces and pages are assigned to your business role using the tool Launchpad Content Manager. Navigate to tab Catalogs. Find and select your business catalog.  In pane Content in Catalog, select the LADI (i.e. tile/TM) and then Display Usages in Pages.

Guidance re the most efficient tools for role-to-catalog assignment:

1. Use the app Launchpad Content Manager Client-Specific to create/change business catalogs + add/remove catalogs to business roles.  Adding the catalog to the business role in the LCM is more efficient (fewer clicks) than using PFCG, and updates the role menu.

2. A mass maintenance alternative  to Launchpad Content Manager Client-Specific where there are many role to catalog assignments is program PRGN_CREATE_FIORI_FRONTENDROLE as explained in Fiori for S/4HANA – Mass maintenance of Business Roles for SAP Fiori launchpad

IMPORTANT: Neither of these tools change the authorizations of the roles. Security administrators can and should adjust authorizations using program PRGN_COMPARE_ROLE_MENU.  

References:

  • SAP Help: SAP Fiori Launchpad – Administration Guide - Creating and Maintaining Launchpad App Descriptor Items and especially subsection Creating Transaction Codes
  • SAP Help – SAP Fiori launchpad – Administration Guide – Setting up Launchpad Content - Best Practices and Typical Scenarios for Setting Up Launchpad Content - Best Practices for Managing Catalogs

 

Understanding Launchpad App Descriptor Items for transactions

If you are new to creating LADI’s, it's a good idea to start by reviewing a LADI for a predefined transaction to understand what details are required and to familiarize yourself with the tooling.

Open the tool Launchpad App Manager. 

You can use the tile on the Fiori Launchpad space assigned to the Fiori Foundation Administration role. This role is generated by task list SAP_FIORI_FOUNDATION_S4 with the default id Z_FIORI_FOUNDATION_ADMIN.

Fiori Launchpad page highlighting the tile Launchpad App Manager

Navigate to the tab Transaction Code and search for a transaction code.

On the tab Transaction Code, searching for transaction VA01, 3 results are listed

Hint: There can be more than one entry if the transaction is used in different use cases with different parameters for different navigational needs. For example, transaction VA01 has some parallel uses for Industry Oil and Gas. Notice that each LADI has a different SemanticObject-Action combination.

Select the link on the technical catalog id to see the details.

Technical catalog id is the first column of the tab Transaction Code. Select the hyperlink on the technical catalog id to view the catalog.

Take a careful note of the assigned Semantic Object.  Arguably the most important field when creating the Launchpad App Descriptor Item is the Semantic Object, as the Semantic Object controls where the navigation links to the GUI transaction appears. For example, in:

  • Related Apps buttons
  • List of links dialogs
  • List of links on process/document flow cards
  • Related apps in Search Results

For some examples of these, refer to my earlier post SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Pro-tips for demonstrating SAP Fiori – Navigate with confidence.

You will also notice that most GUI transactions are marked as not suitable for use on device type = Phone.

IMPORTANT: If you do need to make a SAP GUI transaction available on smartphone, you should consider using SAP Screen Personas to add a mobile layout to the transaction, e.g. using the Slipstream Engine as explained in  blog post Choosing Slipstream Engine or SAP GUI for HTML to render SAP Screen Personas flavors on mobile devices

LADI for transaction VA01 is shown highlighting the Semantic Object SalesDocument. Device Type settings are Desktop enabled, Tablet enabled, Phone disabled.

On the Tiles tab you can see details of the tiles and any keywords

Tiles tab of the LADI shows the tile type (static), tile title, subtitle, keywords, icons, etc.

The Parameters tab lists parameters that may be passed to the transaction when it is launched.

Passing parameters is optional.  Only GUI transactions have Parameters defined as in the example below for transaction FB60. You can see a user Default Value  TaxIsCalculatedAutomatically is passed, and the current supplier id is passed to the field INVFO-ACCNT. The Rename To field is the technical name of the GUI transaction field where the value will be passed.  If no value is maintained in Rename To the value is passed to the field of the same name as the Parameter itself.

Hints:

  • You can usually only pass parameters to the initial screen of a SAP GUI transaction. This is a restriction of SAP GUI.
  • Which parameters are passed depends on the context, i.e. where and how the app was launched.  For example, when the app is launched from a tile, default values are passed. When an app is launched from another app, values in the current context of the app can be passed.

Parameters tab of the LADI shows 2 parameters may be passed, a Default Value and/or the Supplier.

How to create a Launchpad App Descriptor Item for a GUI transaction

Open the tool Launchpad App Manager.

Navigate to the tab Technical Catalogs.

You can add your LADI to an existing custom technical catalog, or you can create a new technical catalog of type standard catalog. Technical catalogs are essentially lists of available app descriptors to use on the launchpad, so they can hold many LADIs. It’s common practice to have one technical catalog per functional area or sub-functional area. You might have some additional technical catalogs for common “every user” apps, administration/support apps, etc.

Hint: A standard catalog can hold any combination of UI content.

To create a new technical catalog, you select the New Standard Catalog button.

Launchpad App Manager showing the Technical Catalogs tab. The button New Standard Catalog is highlighted and appears in the table toolbar.

Give your catalog an id and a title. The recommended naming convention for technical catalogs is Z_TC_xxxxx.  Make sure the title is human readable so that you can find it again later.

Assign transport details when asked, i.e. package and workbench request.

 

Technical catalog id follows the naming convention Z_TC_xxxx. The technical catalog title is user-meaningful. Package and transport request have been entered. The Create Empty Technical Catalog Only flag is checked.

 

Once you have found or created your technical catalog, select the technical catalog id to open it.

On the tab Technical Catalogs, the hyperlink on the technical catalog id Z_TC_ADMIN_APPS is highlighted.

Select menu button Add App then Add Transaction

The technical catalog Z_TC_ADMIN_APPS is opened in Edit mode. The toolbar menu button Add App is open. The sub option Add Transaction are highlighed.

 

Add transport details for the LADI entry, i.e. package and workbench request.  Make sure you use the same package as the technical catalog. 

In the dialog Select Transport Request, the Package and Transport Request are entered.

 

Enter transaction and press the <ENTER> key.

Several of the LADI fields will be defaulted. For example: Device Type, Application Component, and Tile title. These defaults are derived from the SAP GUI transaction definition which you can view in transaction SE93.  In the example below you can see the defaults for the configuration transaction /UI2/FLP_CUS_CONF. You can overwrite these defaults if you wish.

Hint: The application component is primarily useful for support. It will be shown when the user selects the About information or App Support in the User Menu.  Refer to SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – New improvements in App Support

Details of the LADI are shown highlighting fields updated on pressing <ENTER> including the device type checkboxes, the application component, and a Tile is created

 

In the tab Tiles, a tile has been created automatically. Within the tile definition, the tile title is derived from the transaction text in SE93.  The tile keyword is set to the transaction code by default, so that users can find the transaction by its tcode when using the search bar feature Search on Apps.  This is especially helpful for existing business users transitioning from SAP GUI to SAP Fiori, as these users typically know many of their tcodes already. 

An example of the tab Tiles showing the Tile Title and Tile Keyword fields

Select a suitable Semantic Object. You can search using the application component or by text. 

Recommendation: To maximize the benefits of intent-based navigation, use an existing SAP predefined Semantic Object. SAP delivers more than 3K semantic objects.   You can find the complete list in transaction /UI2/SEMOBJ_SAP.  For example, for a custom transaction related to Sales Orders using the Semantic Object SalesOrder or SalesDocument means your custom transaction will be automatically provided in app-to-app navigation features of other Sales Order apps.  For example, your custom transaction will appear as a link in Related Apps, list of links dialogs, search results etc. 

IMPORTANT:   Do NOT create Z versions of SAP Semantic Objects as this removes the benefit of intent-based navigation.  For example, do NOT create a Semantic Object called ZSalesOrder - as this will not provide any app-to-app navigation links to other apps.  In the very rare case where you need to create a custom semantic object, you must create these in transaction /UI2/SEMOBJ before creating the LADI. 

Example of the value help dialog for Semantic Objects. You can search for semantic objects using the application component, or by keyword.

Add an action name as a verb in camelCase, e.g. editConfigurationParameters. You can freely define the action name.  

Hint: To clearly separate custom actions from SAP actions, some customers prefer to start custom actions with a "z".  e.g. zeditConfigurationParameters. 

Recommendation: The combination of SemanticObject-Action should be unique for each intent-based navigation use case.  

Example of the LADI tab Target Application Fields showing the Action field set to the custom action editConfigurationParameters

 

Add a link text in the field Target Application Title. The link text will be seen by the business user whenever a link is provided to navigate to the app, instead of a tile. For example, when navigating from Search results, from Related Apps, from list of links dialogs, etc.

Example of the LADI tab Target Application fields showing the Target Application Title field that holds the link text

Optionally on the Tiles tab you can add tile subtitle, information text, and icon.

Example of the LADI tab Tiles highlighting the Subtitle, Tile Information, Tile icon fields

You need to enter the icon name prefixed with sap-icon:// e.g. sap-icon://customize

Hint: You can use the value help on the tile icon field, or find available SAP icon names in the Icon Explorer. Author's note: Personally I find it easier to pick and choose my icon using the Icon Explorer where I can search for icons by keywords, compare similar icons, view how the icon appears, and review the tags to get some idea of its intended usage.

 

SAP Icon Explorer showing the resulting icons found when searching on the keyword "customize" and the sap-icon:// value of a selected icon in the Copy section

Once you are satisfied with your LADI details, Save your entry.

Your new Launchpad App Descriptor Item (LADI) is now ready for use.  For example: the LADI can be referenced in a business catalog, assigned via the business catalog to a business role, optionally added to a page, etc.

You can come back and change the entry any time in the Launchpad App Manager. Changes will be automatically and immediately reflected wherever the LADI is referenced.

Improve Navigation with Parameters

Parameters can be passed to your SAP GUI Transaction from the current context in SAP Fiori. For the user, passing relevant parameters reduces typing and avoids mistakes. You can pass:

  • Default Values on launch of the transaction
  • Context values from a source app during app-to-app navigation
  • Predefined defaults to a field or to the OK-Code

To pass a parameter to a SAP GUI transaction, the transaction must be able to accept it, such as fields on the initial entry screen of the transaction.

Hint: If you need to pass parameters to a subsequent screen of a transaction, consider using SAP Screen Personas scripting.

You will need to know the technical screen field name of the target field.  You can find this from the technical information in the context menu of the field as shown below.

Example of GUI transaction VA01 showing the context menu on field Order Type. The menu option Help (F1) is highlighted

 

Within the Field Help dialog, select the Technical Information button.

Example of the field help dialog. The technical information button is highlighted

 

Find the Dynpro Field in the section Field description for Batch Input. The Dynpro Field is the technical screen field name.

Example of the Technical Information dialog for field Order Type. The Dynpro field is highlighted in the section Field Description for Batch Input

 

You can also pass values to the Ok Code and – provided all mandatory fields on the initial screen are filled – you can pass a value to skip the initial screen. To pass a value to the OkCode, set your technical OkCode code as the static Default Value and Rename To = DYNP_OKCODE. To skip the first screen, set Default Value = 1 and Rename To = DYNP_NO1ST.

 

Example of Parameters for transaction VA02 highlighting the Rename To column. Values are also passed to DYNP_OKCODE and DYNP_NO1ST

 

Becoming a SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA guru

You’ll find much more on our  SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA topic page

Brought to you by the SAP S/4HANA RIG and Customer Care team

entry.title: Dashboard and Business AI Insights for SAP License Simulation and Analysis
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP has introduced the SAM4U solution, an excellent tool to gather data from SAP backend systems for the consolidation and analysis of users, engines, and HANA EE license consumption.

The Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption, available on SAP Store, provides extended analytics and simulation capabilities to view SAM4U data from new angles. It empowers customers moving to S/4HANA, S/4HANA Private Cloud, or already working under an SAP RISE contract to run different “what if” scenarios based on data extracted from their SAP system, helping them find the best approach to optimize SAP license consumption.

What Was Missing?

While SAM4U provides valuable transparency, customers often asked:

  • How do I see the potential savings?

  • How do I define a strategy for optimization?

  • Where exactly should I focus my cleanup efforts?

License optimization typically falls into three categories:

  • Fast optimization: achieved quickly with user data cleanup in SAP backend

  • Obtainable optimization: achievable in reasonable time with cleanup and role/profile tuning

  • Maximal optimization: the long-term goal, achieved when roles and authorizations are precisely aligned with actual usage

What was missing was clarity and insights to navigate these paths effectively.

How it is solved

The new release of the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption brings two major updates:

  • Clarity through an extremely informative dashboard

  • Business AI insights powered by the Skybuffer AI platform, an SAP Business AI certified solution from SAP Store

The dashboard

This is the highlight. The dashboard presents clear KPIs on one page, helping to get insights into current estimated spending and estimated savings, following both fast and obtainable strategies.

 Pic. 1 The Dashboard

One of the central KPIs is License Optimization Potential, which shows the estimated current contract costs compared to optimized contract costs. The KPI highlights savings that can be achieved either through the fast users cleanup approach or the obtainable approach of cleaning up users and optimizing roles with the highest optimization potential.

 Pic. 2 License Optimization Potential

There are many other useful insights. For example, it shows how many authorization objects are not used at all. This is a target for maximal optimization and one reason it is not so easily obtainable. The lower the number, the better the authorizations are aligned with active usage.

 Pic. 3 Excess Authorization

The evaluation of maximal optimization is also visualized by the FUE Gap KPI:

 Pic. 4 FUE Gap - Authorization vs Active Usage

There is also a very helpful hint about SAP_ALL and SAP_NEW profiles still in use in production:

 Pic. 5 Users with Sensitive Authorization Profiles

The total number of roles and profiles that can be optimized and the savings this brings are also clearly summarized:

 Pic. 6 Excess Roles

The insights

Business AI insights in the dashboard bring extra clarity and understanding. For example, they show the fast optimization saving potential and provide clear explanations and strategies on how to reach it:

Pic. 7 Business AI Insights

AI recommendations are also available for obtainable or maximal optimization:

 Pic. 8 Max and Obtainable Optimization

Effectively, this functions as a personal SAP License Analysis and Optimization consultant, virtualized and trained to understand the organization’s own data.

The AI Assistant is always there, and expanding its knowledge base is straightforward through the Skybuffer AI platform. For example, it can present the top 10 roles for optimization or provide additional information related to SAP licensing:

 Pic. 9 Top 10 Roles for Optimization

Of course, all the well-established simulation and analysis tools of the Accelerator remain available. With the new release, they work even better, helping to test and simulate the AI Assistant’s recommendations.

Conclusion

The Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption now provides one of the most powerful toolsets on the market to analyze and optimize SAP users and engines licenses independently. It helps avoid the significant costs of SAP license optimization consulting and delivers deep insights into user and engine data. This comes without the need for a complex SAM4U installation and without spending time and money on consulting services that quickly become outdated.

What to do next?

Running SAP under a RISE contract? Use the dashboard and Business AI insights at least once per month to avoid FUE consumption increases and surprises. Train your team with the solution and the organization will not face unpredictable growth of SAP license consumption. Leave consulting for the exceptional case when the company grows faster than its SAP role set. 😉

entry.title: ABAP AI - Chapter 2
entry.content:
Summary

  • New ABAP AI capabilities keep coming
  • Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities remain free of charge
  • Availability of ABAP AI in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition in release 2025 is ahead of us
  • ABAP AI will be available in older releases of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition as well, details and updates expected at TechEd.

In February 2025, we started the first chapter of ABAP AI and announced that Joule speaks ABAP. Now, it’s time to get ready for chapter 2!

In the past months, we have been delivering more Joule skills to speed up ABAP Cloud development, and we are now able to create RAP business objects – from the database table up to the UI service powered by generative AI. We can create unit tests, explain code, complete code in the editor, implement validations and determinations, and much more (see also our public slide deck). All these skills are part of the 2508 release of SAP BTP ABAP Environment and SAP Cloud ERP (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition), and they will be included in the SAP Cloud ERP Private (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition) in the 2025 release. Please check out our updated tutorial on ABAP AI capabilities. In addition, we will continue to expand our AI scope and will deliver on the transformation aspect of our AI strategy. This starts with the 2025 delivery for SAP Cloud ERP Private, followed by AI capabilities in the custom code migration app in SAP BTP ABAP Environment 2602. Please visit our roadmap to keep track of our deliveries.

Let’s continue with commercials and keep it short: The free promotions we introduced at the beginning of the year have been extended until further notice! We are convinced that, in the current situation, we don’t want to put any commercial barriers on our offering and let all customers and partners benefit from AI-driven development. The corresponding material numbers for customers 8019124 and TDD partners 8019541 remain the same and can be ordered again. For those who started before the extension of the promotion, note that a re-ordering of the material is required. The procedure for the SAP BTP ABAP Environment and SAP Cloud ERP remains the same as well, and the initial blog post has been updated to reflect this, as well as SAP Note 3571857.
For SAP Cloud ERP Private, as of release 2025, the material numbers are also valid. However, the configuration will need to be done manually by you. Detailed information on this will follow.

But that is not enough. Will ABAP AI capabilities become available also for older releases of SAP Cloud ERP Private? Yes!
Imagine an ABAP AI service running side-by-side to your ABAP instance, providing full access to ABAP AI capabilities across hybrid landscapes. This includes SAP BTP ABAP Environment, SAP Cloud ERP, and SAP Cloud ERP Private. New AI innovations become available independently of release upgrades or support packages, allowing immediate leveraging.  Best of all, this ABAP AI service can also be connected to older releases of SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Sounds like a dream? Let’s find out – stay tuned for TechEd 2025 to receive all the news and updates!

entry.title: How to Add Custom Tables for Local Extensions Calculation in SAP Variant Configuration & Pricing
entry.content:
SAP Variant Configuration & Pricing (VC&P) is a powerful tool for managing complex product configurations. Often, standard tables may not suffice for specific business logic, and you may need to introduce custom tables to support local extensions in pricing or configuration calculations.

This blog walks you through the steps to add a custom table and use it effectively in your local extensions logic.

Why Use Custom Tables?

Custom tables allow you to:

  • Store additional data not available in standard SAP tables.
  • Implement business-specific logic.
  • Enhance flexibility in pricing or configuration rules.

Step-by-Step Guide

Step 1: Create the Custom Table in SAP

Use transaction SE11 to create a transparent table.

  • Define fields relevant to your logic (e.g., product ID, region, surcharge).
  • Set appropriate data types and key fields.
  • Activate the table.

Step 2: Populate the Table

Use SM30 or a custom program to maintain entries in your table.

Step 3: Create a Function Module or ABAP Class

This will serve as the interface between your custom table and the VC&P logic.

  • Use SE37 or SE24.
  • Read data from your custom table based on input parameters.
  • Return the required value (e.g., surcharge, discount).

Step 4: Register the Function Module in VC&P

In the VC&P environment 

  • Go to the Local Extensions section.
  • Upload your javascript file in uploaded zip file and Register your function module or class.
  • Mapped input/output parameters.
  • Active Local Extensions - you will see the Function Name which will be active 

Step 5: Use the Custom Table in Calculation Logic

Now you can use your custom logic in:

  • Pricing procedures
  • Configuration rules
  • Condition records

Step 6: Add the Custom Tables 

Step 1 - Click on Tables from left menu - 2nd Tab - Custom tables

Step 2 - (Important Disclaimer and must to read) and Click Next

Step 3 - Add the custom tables in table list row by row and Click Submit and Select checkbox - Next Step

Step 4 - Custom table added will process and trigger to update the records into tables - you will see Running Queue starts

Example Use Case

Imagine you want to apply a regional surcharge based on the product and customer location. Your custom table might look like:

Product ID Region Surcharge (%)
P1001EU5
P1001US7
Your function module reads this table and returns the surcharge to be applied in the pricing logic.

Best Practices

  • Use naming conventions for custom objects.
  • Document your logic clearly.
  • Test thoroughly in a sandbox before moving to production.

entry.title: Release Navigator for SAP Cloud ERP Private – What’s New in Q3 2025
entry.content:
Greetings Community!

I am excited to announce the upcoming 2025 FPS00 release for SAP Cloud ERP (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition), scheduled for October. To ensure a smooth transition and help you prepare for the upgrade, the release navigator for SAP Cloud ERP Private will be undergoing enhancements over the next month. These updates will include new UX features and content designed to support your readiness journey. As a reminder, all updates to the release navigator are completely automated and taken care by SAP Enterprise Support.

Topics

  1. Quick Links
  2. New Topics & Content
  3. New & Refreshed UX Features
  4. Release Navigator Innovation Plan
  5. Connect with Us

 

Click on the links below to access each resource:

 

Additional Sub-Topics for Supply Chain

In October, I am happy to share the expansion of our Supply Chain page with two new, highly requested sub-topics:

  1. Extended Warehouse Management (EWM)
  2. Transportation Management (TM)

Within these sub-topics, users will have access to curated release content aligned with the 2025 FPS00 updates. This enhancement aims to provide a more comprehensive and detailed resource hub, enabling you to stay informed about the latest developments in these critical areas of supply chain management.

 

Extended Warehouse Management for Supply Chain

Under the EWM sub-topic on the Supply Chain page, you will find the following resources:

  1. What’s New Viewer
  2. Release Blog
  3. Help Portal
  4. Onboarding Resource Center

 

 Transportation Management for Supply Chain

Under the TM sub-topic on the Supply Chain page, you will find the following resources:

  1. What’s New Viewer
  2. Release Blog
  3. Help Portal
  4. Onboarding Resource Center

 

SAP Activate Interactive Framework for Upgrades

The SAP Activate Road Map serves as an indispensable guide for SAP Cloud ERP Private customers, expertly navigating them through the intricacies of upgrade phases, deliverables, tasks, and accelerators. Aligned with the SAP Cloud Framework, it clearly outlines responsibilities for customers and partners, facilitating enhanced features, robust security, and seamless collaboration under a unified governance model.

For those seeking a comprehensive view of the tasks required for a smooth upgrade, the interactive framework offers an intuitive solution. Users can select from a range of upgrade tasks to gain a clear understanding of the necessary steps, ensuring a well-organized and efficient upgrade process.

 

 

All Pages

Search

I am excited to introduce a new search button conveniently located in the shell bar of all pages, designed to help you quickly locate release content for topics of interest. Simply:

  1. Open the search window
  2. Enter the desired topic
  3. Click on the relevant resource to view the corresponding content.

Should you encounter any difficulties in finding a specific topic, we encourage you to submit a request through our user feedback page.

 

Product Specific Page

Release Calendar

I am also happy to announce that the release calendar within the Product Specific page has been revamped with a fresh design. It now offers a more detailed view of the release schedule, allowing you to see the specific week when releases will be made available to customers. This granular insight enables you to plan and prepare more effectively for upcoming updates.

 

General Page

Content Structure

We have restructured the General page to better serve your needs. It is now organized by SAP Activate phases, providing clear guidance on when to utilize specific resources during each phase. This alignment with the Road Map Viewer is designed to enhance your navigation experience and ensure you have the right information at the right time.

 

About this Card

I would also like to highlight an additional feature on the General page that enhances your understanding of each resource. You can now access more information about each resource by simply selecting the triple dot icon located at the bottom of each card. This toggle function allows you to reveal or hide further details as needed, ensuring you have all the relevant information at your fingertips.

 

This section provides information regarding the release navigator only. For more detailed information on product release dates, please refer to the Release Calendar card on the Product Specific page.

 Disclaimer: These dates are for informational purposes only and may change. The Readiness@Scale team has the final decision over any UX modifications. Thank you for understanding.

 

We value your input and encourage you to share any feedback or specific content requests for future updates to the release navigator. Please feel free to complete our feedback survey or contribute your suggestions in the Comments section below this post.

To explore more about how the Readiness@Scale team is dedicated to overseeing release readiness within the SAP Enterprise Support portfolio, visit our Release Ready page. Additionally, you can find all our team's blog posts by searching the tag  Readiness@Scale. Thank you for your continued engagement and support.

 

Always bring your best,

Andrew Ford
SAP Enterprise Support
